comments.body: Don't forget to do the same for ``AggregationCursor<T>``and remove overriding methods of ``Collection`` (like ``find()``) that return ``Cursor<any>`` and ``AggregationCursor<any>``. They are unnecessary now.
You are right, I forgot to update the `AggregationCursor`. I'll try to do it today. Thanks for the reminder!

Can you add an `@deprecated` to the description of count on [line 496](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/27008/files/d2d46bcd46b775c64dcc7bfad8b07e9901fceb12#diff-2b1325c7d29dbe7167881a665318da51R496) so the deprecated status if reflected here?
Done. I've added a @deprecated sign per comment, under the URL to be consistent with insertOne, remove, etc. Thanks.

Thanks, just a nitpick. It would be better if the deprecated where in the same jsdoc comment so the editors show both
Like:
```ts
/** 
 * http://mongodb.github.io/node-mongodb-native/3.1/api/Collection.html#count
 * @deprecated Use countDocuments or estimatedDocumentCount 
 */
 count(callback: MongoCallback<number>): void;
```
Updated. cheers.
Can you also update `CommonOptions ` at line 455 and `GridFSBucketWriteStreamOptions ` at line 1626 to make them extend this interface? Just to avoid duplicating the interfaces

updated the interface 9c3770f940c74b04b66a71156d52f42fbc6e037a
unfortunately the options of  GridFSBucketWriteStreamOptions differ from WriteConcern
Is it necessary to pollute this change with what are effectively stylistic changes?

There was bunch of various styles how identifiers are documented, one were documented with line comments others used block comments and my intention was it to unifies these comments.

I decide to use doc comments for the following reason: To my knowledge the most ideas only supports docs comments (block comments) for rendering in editor documentation. For example vscode don't displays the property/method documentation, if it was documented with one line comments.
If you mean the replacement of the comma with the semicolon, as i said it's was my intent to unify the code. All other ObjectType definition uses semicolons.
I think the typing benefits from the unification of documentation styling.
In the future it would be better to do the stylistic changes as separate commits (even if in the same PR). Makes it easier to review!
single block comment also here

@@ -1,1 +466,470 @@     *
     * If null, will attempt to connect with IPv6, and will fall back to IPv4 on failure
     * refer to http://mongodb.github.io/node-mongodb-native/3.1/api/MongoClient.html
     */
    family?: 4 | 6 | null;

comments.body: I think narrowing the type of a parameter is a breaking change.  I'm assuming that this is a general improvement and doesn't correspond to a change in the library version, so the usual mitigation of updating the .d.ts version won't help.  Has the cost of the break been weighed against the benefits?

As mentioned, in the other part of the library this change has already been merges, like in the update method. So I think the breaking change impact would be minor compared to the previous changes and the library would gain in consistency.
We can maybe add a comment to indicate that this is needed until the typescript version is lower than 3.5
Done

I did not add the GeoJSON types and dependency to `geojson` package as [`geojson` requires typescript 2.3](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/0babfb3d33e8821db5b140517d3e032a62f4752d/types/geojson/index.d.ts#L9) and updating it and all of its dependencies to TS 2.8. I think we can add it in another PR.
Would you please specify the type of the callback at least? or use generic from distinct or the Collection?

The callback can return `any` as you can specify any key and it can any data-type in the database.

We could potentially make it check if it can extract `TSchema[key]`, but as this PR doesn't touch the callback (this line is just duplicated from the ones below) I think that that belongs in a separate PR.
Actually, more correct is probably `any[]`. But I'd rather submit that as a second PR as it isn't related to the changes I did now...
Last... may you please write some tests?
we don't have types on the repo that we can import?
The eventemitter types in node do not support this, no.

comments.body:
The callback here will not receive any data:

```suggestion
    abort(callback?: GridFSBucketErrorCallback<void>): void;
```
Could you please add break lines between properties to fit the existing code style?
@xamgore thx for the review! resolved with f508693d12

Why is `any` allowed here?

According to https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/method/db.collection.find/#find-projection, only `0`, `1`, `true`, `false` and the `ProjectionOperators` are allowed.

That was originally what I thought :D 
But @HitkoDev notice me the MongoDB 4.4 introduced aggregation expression in projection(https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/reference/method/db.collection.find/#find-projection), for example: `{maxInArray: {$max: ['$array', 0]}}`, and it's hard to typing the aggregation expression and maybe some operator not support in projection. 

So for now I added `any` to projection, or have a better solution?
Is every change in this PR correct for 3.5 as well? If not, the version in the header needs to be bumped too.

MongoDB 4.4 is only _fully_ supported in driver version 3.6. 

Changes in this PR, however, work with driver version 3.5 (and probably even some earlier versions), since the driver just forwards those inputs to the server.
There's a related property `maxAwaitTimeMS`, which should be used with `awaitData`.

```suggestion
```

This option was removed in MongoDB 3.4, and the typings are for 3.6

ref: https://stackoverflow.com/a/41783524/148072
We should maybe keep this property to let the developers using this one know that is deprecated before removing it ?
Giving a chance to make this discussion
You should add a test calling this function without the `options` parameter to prevent future regression

Right, that's why I made this small edit to the existing test [here](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/51073/files#diff-6b5da2618493adf61d45da47ff1a6f6721cea888c0d7e94a5e8754988ad6d342R84)

There is then coverage for:
- `findOne` with no generic and no options
- `findOne` with a generic and no options
- `findOne` with a generic and options

What did I miss?
My bad
All good, thanks for making sure I did this right!
